content.brief: Discover easy steps you can take to improve your cybersecurity
content.extended: Discover easy steps you can take to improve your cybersecurity
content.micro: Easy steps to improving your cybersecurity.
There is no infallible way to guarantee your safety on the internet, but these tips can prevent you from being an easy target for hackers.
In addition to applying the principles from the tips for home users, these steps can be used to help secure your organization.
For more tips on protecting yourself or your organization, see the resources below.
We're listening!

Cyber.gov is the website of the Office of Management and Budget’s Cyber and National Security Unit (OMB Cyber), the United States Chief Information Security Officer, and the Chief Information Security Officers Council. Cyber.gov serves as a central collection of cybersecurity policies, best practices, and other resources in order to inform the public about cybersecurity regardless of their level of technical knowledge.

Most of the material on Cyber.gov website is created by Federal employees, and you may reproduce, publish or otherwise use it without permission consistent with the Copyright Act of 1976. Please consider appropriate citation to Cyber.gov as the source. Copyrighted materials may also appear on this website, or may be reached through a link on this website. Copyright and other intellectual property laws may apply to your use of those materials.

Most images found on Cyber.gov were licensed for use by the Cyber.gov from a stock photography service or other copyright holder, who may prohibit republication, retransmission, reproduction, or any other use of the images.

Protecting the privacy and security of individuals’ personal information is very important to us. We do not collect any information that directly identifies you when you visit cyber.gov unless you choose to provide that information by contacting us. However, the website may collect a limited amount of information about your visit for the purposes of website analytics and customization. Please read this notice to understand what we do with the limited amount of information about your visit that we may collect.

content.brief: View Federal agency performance key cybersecurity capabilities, in support of an open, secure, and transparent government.
content.extended: Explore Federal agency performance on key cybersecurity metrics, in support of an open and transparent government.
content.micro: Explore Federal cybersecurity performance metrics.

Established by the Government Performance and Results Modernization Act (GPRA) of 2010, the Cross-Agency Priority (CAP) Goals aim to accelerate progress on a limited number of Presidential priority areas where implementation requires active collaboration between multiple agencies. The OMB Cyber and National Security Unit, in partnership with the National Security Council, Department of Homeland Security, and Department of Defense, drives implementation of the cybersecurity CAP Goal amongst the federal agencies. This CAP Goal has a mission statement of, “Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.”

In accordance with the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA), the annual report provides Congress and the public information on agency progress towards meeting cybersecurity performance goals and identifies areas in need of improvement. This report also provides information on Federal cybersecurity incidents, ongoing efforts to mitigate and prevent future incidents, and agencies’ progress in implementing cybersecurity policies and programs to protect their systems, networks, and data.

content.brief: The Federal Government offers a wide range of dynamic cybersecurity education and training opportunities.
content.micro: The Federal Government offers a wide range of dynamic cybersecurity education and training opportunities.
Resources for students of all ages to help them jump start their career in cybersecurity or a related field.
Resources for educators of all grade levels to help their students become interested in and learn more about cybersecurity.
Webinars, classes, and other materials for cybersecurity awareness training.

content.brief: Read about our strategy to harden the Federal cybersecurity workforce, and discover opportunities for Federal service.
content.extended: Read about our strategy to harden the Federal cybersecurity workforce, and discover opportunities for Federal service.
content.micro: Learn about Federal cybersecurity career opportunities.

On July 12, 2016, the White House released the first-ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy, which details government-wide actions to identify, expand, recruit, develop, retain and sustain a capable and competent workforce to address complex and ever-evolving cyber threats.

content.brief: Resources for Cybersecurity professionals within the Federal Government. These documents should be considered a ‘reading list’ to help acquaint new employees to the Federal cybersecurity policy environment.
content.micro: Resources for Cybersecurity professionals within the Federal Government. These documents should be considered a ‘reading list’ to help acquaint new employees to the Federal cybersecurity policy environment.
Statute or laws as passed by the United States Congress as they relate to requirements placed on Federal agencies.
Legally binding orders issued by the President to direct Federal agencies and officials in their execution of congressionally established laws or policies.

sections.title: Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Policies

content.micro: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) puts forth policy memorandums (M-memos) and circulars to provide instructions, information, guidance, rules, and/or background information on legislative or procedural matters to Federal agencies.

sections.title: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Standards

content.micro: Generally accepted guides by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) that serve as a template or ideal standard for enterprise cybersecurity programs.

content.brief: The implementation of best practices and proper cyber hygiene can help prevent many cyber incidents and data breaches. The Federal Government is focused on reducing cyber risk by implementing best practices that do the right things the right way at the right time. The following is a collection of resources that can help IT managers and operators efficiently manage risk. This is not an exhaustive list and all users are encouraged to help grow the repository by providing feedback to OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov.

content.brief: Learn more about the Federal Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council, a body dedicated to protecting the People's data.
content.extended: Learn more about the Federal Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council, a body dedicated to protecting the People's data.
content.micro: Learn more about the CISO Council.
The Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council is the principal inter-agency forum uniting agencies’ efforts to strengthen the cybersecurity posture of the United States Government.

content.brief: Promote an open and transparent government that protects the People’s information while preserving privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.
content.extended: Promote an open and transparent government that protects the People’s information while preserving privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.
content.micro: Find out how we plan to protect the People's IT.
The cybersecurity strategy of the United States Government is executed along five lines of effort.

Taking bold actions to protect Americans in today’s digital world. 

From buying products to running businesses to finding directions to communicating with the people we love, an online world has fundamentally reshaped our daily lives.  But just as the continually evolving digital age presents boundless opportunities for our economy, our businesses, and our people, it also presents a new generation of threats that we must adapt to meet.  Criminals, terrorists, and countries who wish to do us harm have all realized that attacking us online is often easier than attacking us in person.  As more and more sensitive data is stored online, the consequences of those attacks grow more significant each year.  

Meeting these new threats is necessary and within our grasp.  But it requires a bold reassessment of the way we approach security in the digital age.  If we’re going to be connected, we need to be protected.  We need to join together—Government, businesses, and individuals—to sustain the spirit that has always made America great. 

 The Cybersecurity National Action Plan (CNAP) is the capstone of more than seven years of determined effort, building upon lessons learned from cybersecurity trends, threats, and intrusions.  This plan directs the Federal Government to take bold action and fosters the conditions required for long-term improvements in our approach to cybersecurity across the Federal Government, the private sector, and our personal lives.
